data.text:
Post by morrisondylanfan on

Hi all,I hope everyone is having a good week,and I want to ask what are your favourite books on film or TV?

My favourites: (Apart from top one,in no order.):

The Wonderful World of Disney Television: A Complete History by Bill Cotter,

Going to an NEC fair in Birmingham to sell Comic books with my dad in 97/98 I took £20 pocket money along. Spending part of it on getting a photo with Judge Dredd, (on a stage with robots/ large props from the 1995 film,that actually looked really cool) I looked round the various other traders tables, and for the first time saw a book that I had to buy right on the spot. Years before before YouTube, tor, ease to find Region 1 DVDs to import, the extensive detailed reviews/episode guides opened my eyes to a world of Disney which I had not known existed.

Murderous Passions: and Flowers of Perversion: The Delirious Cinema of Jesus Franco by Stephen Thrower and Julian Grainger.

Weighing 4.1 pounds and 5.5 pounds each and taking a decade to write, Thrower and Grainger present a heavyweight tribute to "Uncle" Jess Franco. Covering over 200 movies, the passion that the writers have for JF comes across even when searching for highlights in his low points, with the writers also going into detail on his lost and never produced works.

Sin in Soft Focus: Pre-Code Hollywood by Mark A. Vieira.

Filled with alluring stills, Vieira offers a breathless tour to the mad-cap antics that went on behind and in front of the camera in this sadly short-lived era of Hollywood.

Nightmare Movies by Kim Newman.

Extensively updating his original book, Newman digs into themes and the continued evolving of Horror sub-genres from the late 1950's-to now, with new, detailed analysis on Horror auteurs from De Palma and Argento to GDT and Tim Burton.

A Pictorial History of Horror Movies by Denis Gifford was one of the first books I got and I still have it.

Also Classics of the Horror Film and More Classics of the Horror Film.

The Master of the Majicks books on Ray Harryhausen I got a while ago (although they updated it after he died).

Vampire Cinema by David Pirie

Beating the Devil: The Making of Night of the Demon (glad I got it when I did since it goes for a lot now)

I wanted to ask someone who has the "Insert Studio" Story books which do they like best?

I have:

The Warner Bros. Story

The RKO Story

The Hammer Story (I assume it is the same series but its pretty thin compared to the others).

Post by mikef6 on

I dipped into my copy of "Sin In Soft Focus" earlier this week.

Some Great Biographies That Give A Lot Of Background About Film Production. I refer often to these titles

Robert Mitchum: “Baby, I Don’t Care” by Lee Server

Stan And Ollie: The Roots Of Comedy: The Double Life Of Laurel And Hardy by Simon Louvish

Bogart by A.M. Sperber and Eric Lax

Alfred Hitchcock: A Life In Darkness And Light by Patrick McGilligan

Groucho: The Life And Times Of Julius Henry Marx by Stefan Kanfer

On Sunset Boulevard: The Life And Times Of Billy Wilder by Ed Sikov

The Beatles: The Biography by Bob Spitz

Others I frequently use:

Agee on Film by James Agee. (Also in a Library of America collection). Contemporary reviews of now classic films. Agee is considered by many to be the first true movie reviewer.

You Ain’t Heard Nothing Yet: The American Talking Film: History and Memory: 1927-1949 by Andrew Sarris. I’ve never read this all the way through - it is divided up into many individual topic chapters for browsing - but whenever I have dipped into it, I have been educated.

Saturday Night At The Bijou by David Zinman. A look at some of the most popular of the movie series of the classic era. Production histories of the likes of Charlie Chan, Mr. Moto, Andy Hardy, Crime Doctor, Nancy Drew and about two dozen others.

Post by Prime etc. on

Hi Prime, from the Amazon outline Beating the Devil: The Making of Night of the Demon (well done getting it at a good price!) sounds like a really interesting read. What was the main thing you learnt on the making of Night of the Demon (which recently came out on a Blu Ray Region Free special edition from Indicator,which I recommend) from the book?

The main thing is that the demon, contrary to frequent claims, was always intended to be shown as real, and not suggested as being ambiguous or possibly a figment of his imagination--which has been repeated numerous times, even by the director.

The demon had to be shown as real in order to build suspense from the fact that Holden is a skeptic, but the curse is real and he needs to learn this. Whether they showed the demon too much is another thing, but in the script it is not meant to be ambiguous.

www.amazon.com/Forbidden-Hollywood-Pre-Code-1930-1934-Classic/dp/0762466774/ref=sr_1_1?crid=11UVJMOLFDJRI&keywords=forbidden+hollywood&qid=1550196453&s=books&sprefix=forbidden+holl%2Cdigital-text%2C235&sr=1-1

I can't tell for certain but it looks like it may be a new book with new material or a different perspective. After all, "Sin in Soft Focus" will be 20 years old this year. I looked at Vieira's web site for info and saw the book cover picture (Gable and Harlow) plus a photo from "Footlight Parade." Neither of those illustrations appear in Sin/Soft Focus. Still, I would want to have a look at the book before making a purchase. As Vieira's site says, "Coming to stores...April 2, 2019!"

Some of my favorites over the years:

Dennis Gifford's A Pictoral History of Horror Movies

Howard B. Jewell and Vernon Harbin's The RKO Story

John Douglas Eames' The Paramount Story

Clive Hirschhorn's The Universal Story

Alex Barris' Hollywoods Other Man

Clive Hirschhorn's The Columbia Story

Clive Hirschhorn's The Warner's Story

James Douglas Eames' The MGM Story

Ronald Bergan's The United Artists Story

Also those The Films of Name Nameson books, that I have of Montgomery Clift, Joan Crawford, Spencer Tracy, Gary Cooper, Peter Lorre, Alan Ladd, Rita Hayworth, Laurence Olivier, Henry Fond and James Cagney.

amd somthing I once bought very cheap but is gold, A Variety Movie Guide, since the reviews are the ones they wrote when many old movies were new.

Many of those books have been very usefull over the last two years here, since not all things can be found on the net. and I usually mention where I found the "facts of what might later have turned out to be fiction"

Post by manfromplanetx on

I have a wonderful collection of old Film Annuals full of nostalgia, info on the lives of the stars and the films of the day. the colourful covers also make for a great shelf display. A favourite annual is the English publication Picture Show Annual sold to the colonies, the first hardback annual was released in 1926 and ran until the early 1961. I have collected all except for three volumes from the war years 44, 45 & 46 which do not seem to exist ?. The annuals were released at the end of each year for the holiday xmas season, the 1926 annual is actually 1925 in film.

An outstanding highlight within the 160 pages is three sections of full page magnificent beautifully toned photographic portraits signed by the stars.
